docs.snippet: Best Bet      The latest group of trout is hatching at the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery and Aquarium and to celebrate the arrival of these Young of the Year (or Y.O.Y.'s, as scientists call them), there's a ''Trout Birthday Party'' today at 2 ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Best Bet The latest group of trout is hatching at the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery and Aquarium and to celebrate the arrival of these Young of the Year (or Y.O.Y.'s, as scientists call them), there's a ''Trout Birthday Party'' today at 2 p.m. Celebrants get to sample the birthday cake, cookies and cider while they sing ''Happy Birthday Baby Trout,'' listen to hatchery personnel talk about the hatching process and the life cycle of the trout, and get up close and personal with the sac-fry in a tank in the Fairchild Building. To see the fish dine, come early at 1 p.m. or stay until 3 p.m. when there are feeding demonstrations. The hatchery is on Route 25A (631) 692-6768.

docs.snippet: Last summer, Adrienne Arsht, chairwoman of TotalBank in Miami, read  Bill Bradley's book, ''Values of the Game.'' A fan of women's sports, Ms. Arsht liked what Mr. Bradley, a former New York Knick, had to say about teamwork, discipline and respons...
docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Adrienne Arsht, chairwoman of TotalBank in Miami, read Bill Bradley's book, ''Values of the Game.'' A fan of women's sports, Ms. Arsht liked what Mr. Bradley, a former New York Knick, had to say about teamwork, discipline and responsibility. So she volunteered to help his insurgent campaign for president. Within weeks, the Bradley campaign called. Could she be the host of a fund-raiser? ''I said, do we do tea sandwiches or what?'' Ms. Arsht, 57, recalled. ''I had never done anything close to this in my life. Not since 1968, when I left my father's law firm in Delaware and went to work for Eugene McCarthy.''
docs.abstract: Bill Bradley raised more than $27 million for his underdog quest for Democratic nomination, just $2 million less than Vice Pres Gore, party's front-runner; with no political machine at his fingertips, and no powerhouse fund-raisers, Bradley turned to loose network of longtime friends and supporters to be his money gatherers; by tapping into many veins of money, many of them from outside usual Democratic contributor lists, Bradley sidestepped what many considered towering obstacle to his campaign: Gore's early success at locking up many of best-known and most-loyal Democratic fund-raisers and contributors; photo (M)

docs.snippet: THERE was a time in the 19th century when boys and girls shared a style of clothing. Both wore frocks -- until the age of 6 when boys began to be dressed in short pants, and were set on the path to manhood. This and other stories of changing attit...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time in the 19th century when boys and girls shared a style of clothing. Both wore frocks -- until the age of 6 when boys began to be dressed in short pants, and were set on the path to manhood. This and other stories of changing attitudes and fashions unfold in ''Images of Childhood: 1800-1900,'' an exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford through Feb. 27. Visitors step from the Morgan Great Hall into the costume and textile galleries.
docs.abstract: Bess Liebenson reviews exhibit on children's fashions, 1800-1900, at Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn; photos (M)

headline.main: Dressing Children In a Century Past

docs.snippet: PRESTON STURGES, who won the first Oscar for best original screenplay in 1940 for ''The Great McGinty,'' followed a simple formula. ''In selling your story,'' he said, ''the first 20 pages are the ones that count. Bob Benchley once said, 'If you'r...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRESTON STURGES, who won the first Oscar for best original screenplay in 1940 for ''The Great McGinty,'' followed a simple formula. ''In selling your story,'' he said, ''the first 20 pages are the ones that count. Bob Benchley once said, 'If you're going to do a stark, realistic Down East drama of the soil, you better start torturing the horses offstage before the first curtain.' '' To the uninitiated, Mr. Sturges might sound like many modern-day screenwriters. He adhered to certain principles and freely borrowed from those he admired. But there the comparisons end. If Mr. Sturges were alive today, he would be faced with a dizzying array of methods to write a screenplay that sells: among them dozens of books and magazines about screenwriting, weekend workshops, charismatic coaches, networking Web sites, Internet script consultants and special software that will not only format your script but also help write it as well.
docs.abstract: Article on growing number of computer programs and traditional courses that would-be Hollywood screenwriters are using to help them write their movies; examples cited; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Voters who attended speeches by Gov. George W. Bush this week in New Hampshire and Iowa got more than just a handshake, a promise and a heady brush with a political celebrity. They got a bound, paperback copy of his collected works.
docs.abstract: Notebook article on Gov George Bush's presidential drive; notes he gave New Hampshire and Iowa voters who attended his speeches paperback copies of his collected works; cites his mangled pronunciation of verb 'obfuscate;' photo (M)8

headline.main: Reporter's Notebook; Voters Can Now Curl Up With the Policies of Bush

docs.snippet: As expected, Ruth Orkin's classic picture ''American Girl in Italy, Florence'' (1951), in which a tall American beauty braves the stares and lusty crudity of men loitering at a street corner, takes pride of place at an exhibition of her work and t...
docs.lead_paragraph: As expected, Ruth Orkin's classic picture ''American Girl in Italy, Florence'' (1951), in which a tall American beauty braves the stares and lusty crudity of men loitering at a street corner, takes pride of place at an exhibition of her work and that of her husband, Morris Engel, at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo. Growing up in Hollywood in the 1920's and 30's and often taken to movie premieres by her mother, Mary Ruby, a silent-screen actress, Orkin developed a superb cinematic eye at an early age and planned to become a film director. But even before she discovered, at age 21, that the cinematographers' union was an all-male preserve, Orkin was heading toward a career in photography. In her teens she was taking black-and-white pictures -- mostly of people, known and unknown, in and around Hollywood -- that were understated, sophisticated and full of quiet drama.

headline.main: Married in Their Vision, But Not Their Styles

docs.snippet: For the first time in seven years, a boxing promoter has decided to venture into New York City with a regular monthly boxing show. The promoter, Cedric Kushner, said yesterday that he will hold his ''Heavyweight Explosion'' cards at the Hammerstei...
docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in seven years, a boxing promoter has decided to venture into New York City with a regular monthly boxing show. The promoter, Cedric Kushner, said yesterday that he will hold his ''Heavyweight Explosion'' cards at the Hammerstein Ballroom in midtown Manhattan on the last Thursday of each month, beginning on Jan. 27. The first card will feature a co-main event, with matches between Kirk Johnson (28-0-1) and Israel Cole (15-9-4), and Monte Barrett (21-1) and Derrick Banks (19-4-1).

headline.main: Monthly Cards Return At Site in Manhattan

docs.snippet: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews...
docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12. Now Playing * ''AMERICAN MOVIE,'' featuring Mark Borchardt and friends. Directed by Chris Smith (R, 104 minutes). An insightful, funny, not-to-be-missed documentary about a no-budget Wisconsin filmmaker who makes a horror film as if his life depended on it. And as Mr. Smith so affectingly reveals, Mr. Borchardt's hopes really do hang in the balance. This knowing and often hilarious look at try-anything indie filmmaking becomes a moving portrait of one man's uphill struggle and finds Mr. Borchardt often describing success and prosperity as his goals. Meanwhile his own life is eloquently presented as a very different, no less authentic kind of American Dream (Janet Maslin).

docs.snippet: CELEBRITIES or would-be celebrities, eager to keep their faces before the fickle public, have a new medium: the cookie.    Five-inch oval cookies in the shape of John Malkovich's head recently became a novel -- though questionably appetizing -- wa...
docs.lead_paragraph: CELEBRITIES or would-be celebrities, eager to keep their faces before the fickle public, have a new medium: the cookie. Five-inch oval cookies in the shape of John Malkovich's head recently became a novel -- though questionably appetizing -- way to promote the film ''Being John Malkovich.'' The cookies were sent to members of the news media to publicize the movie.

headline.main: Head Shots Never Tasted So Good
